title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is aimed at viewpoint protection in communications, amending the Communications Act of 1934 to include provisions for protecting viewpoints. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Federal Communications Commission from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. It also prevents the Commission from imposing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews, except in cases of specific violations of the law. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the FCC from taking action on broadcast content based on viewpoints, except in cases of specific violations of the law. This includes violations of certain sections of the United States Code and public interest obligations under the Act. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the FCC from taking action on broadcast content based on viewpoints, except in cases of specific violations of the law. This includes violations of certain sections of the United States Code, public interest obligations, and incitement under the First Amendment. The President is also restricted from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints in broadcast or disseminated content. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from directing agencies to impose conditions on approvals or decisions based on viewpoints in broadcast content. This does not affect the President's authority to take action on violations of the law. The subsection clarifies that the President retains authority to direct agencies to take action on violations of specific sections of the United States Code, regardless of the content dissemination method. The President has the authority to direct agencies to take action on violations of specific sections of the United States Code, including incitement under the First Amendment, or to execute presidential duties under any provision of law. The term "agency" is defined in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
